segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Exactly so,” said the Hatter: “as the things get used up.”

events.text_segment:
Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter’s remark seemed to have no sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. “I don’t quite understand you,” she said, as politely as she could.
“The Dormouse is asleep again,” said the Hatter, and he poured a little hot tea upon its nose.
The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its eyes, “Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.”
“Have you guessed the riddle yet?” the Hatter said, turning to Alice again.
“No, I give it up,” Alice replied: “what’s the answer?”
“I haven’t the slightest idea,” said the Hatter.
“Nor I,” said the March Hare.
Alice sighed wearily. “I think you might do something better with the time,” she said, “than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.”
“If you knew Time as well as I do,” said the Hatter, “you wouldn’t talk about wasting it. It’s him.”
“I don’t know what you mean,” said Alice.
“Of course you don’t!” the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously. “I dare say you never even spoke to Time!”
“Perhaps not,” Alice cautiously replied: “but I know I have to beat time when I learn music.”
“Ah! that accounts for it,” said the Hatter. “He won’t stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he’d do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o’clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you’d only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!”
(“I only wish it was,” the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)
“That would be grand, certainly,” said Alice thoughtfully: “but then—I shouldn’t be hungry for it, you know.”
“Not at first, perhaps,” said the Hatter: “but you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked.”
“Is that the way you manage?” Alice asked.
The Hatter shook his head mournfully. “Not I!” he replied. “We quarrelled last March—just before he went mad, you know—” (pointing with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) “—it was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing
‘Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
How I wonder what you’re at!’
You know the song, perhaps?”
“I’ve heard something like it,” said Alice.
“It goes on, you know,” the Hatter continued, “in this way:—
‘Up above the world you fly,
Like a tea-tray in the sky.
                    Twinkle, twinkle—’”
Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep “Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle—” and went on so long that they had to pinch it to make it stop.
“Well, I’d hardly finished the first verse,” said the Hatter, “when the Queen jumped up and bawled out, ‘He’s murdering the time! Off with his head!’”
“How dreadfully savage!” exclaimed Alice.
“And ever since that,” the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, “he won’t do a thing I ask! It’s always six o’clock now.”
A bright idea came into Alice’s head. “Is that the reason so many tea-things are put out here?” she asked.
“Yes, that’s it,” said the Hatter with a sigh: “it’s always tea-time, and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles.”
“Then you keep moving round, I suppose?” said Alice.
“Exactly so,” said the Hatter: “as the things get used up.”

Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter's watch had only one hand, and it was moving in a most extraordinary manner. "I don't quite understand," she said politely.

"It's a very long story," said the Hatter, "and it’s all about Time. You see, Time is a person."

"I don't know what you mean," said Alice.

"Of course you don't!" the Hatter exclaimed. "I dare say you never even spoke to Time!"

"Perhaps not," Alice replied, "but I know I have to beat time when I learn music."

"Ah! That accounts for it," said the Hatter. "He won't stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he’d do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o'clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you’d only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!"

"That would be grand, certainly," said Alice thoughtfully.

"Not at all," said the Hatter. "The thing is, we can’t go on changing it. It’s always tea-time, and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles."

"Then you keep moving round, I suppose?" Alice ventured.

"Exactly so," said the Hatter, "as the things get used up."

Just then the Dormouse began singing in its sleep, "Twinkle, twinkle, little bat! How I wonder what you’re at!"

The Hatter pinched the Dormouse on the nose to wake it up.

"What did you say?" he asked.

"I only began to say 'Twinkle, twinkle,'" said the Dormouse, "because it’s the first verse of the song."

"Have you guessed the riddle yet?" the Hatter asked Alice.

"No, I give it up," Alice replied. "What’s the answer?"

"I haven’t the slightest idea," said the Hatter.

"Nor I," said the March Hare.

Alice sighed wearily. "I think you might do something better with the time than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers."

"If you knew Time as well as I do," said the Hatter, "you wouldn’t talk about wasting it. It’s him."

"I don’t know what you mean," said Alice.

"Of course you don’t!" the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously. "I dare say you never even spoke to Time!"

"Perhaps not," Alice cautiously replied, "but I know I have to beat time when I learn music."

"Ah! That accounts for it," said the Hatter. "He won’t stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he’d do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o’clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you’d only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!"

"That would be grand, certainly," said Alice thoughtfully.

"Not at all," said the Hatter. "The thing is, we can’t go on changing it. It’s always tea-time, and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles."

"Then you keep moving round, I suppose?" Alice ventured.

"Exactly so," said the Hatter, "as the things get used up."

"I see," said Alice. "That’s why you have the constant tea-things."

"Exactly so," said the Hatter. "It’s always six o’clock now."

- The original includes the March Hare's whispered aside about wishing it were time for dinner, which is not present in the completion.
- The passage where the Dormouse sings in its sleep and must be pinched to stop is altered and lacks the original's detail and sequence.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The world around her seemed to twist and turn in ways she could not understand. She had followed the White Rabbit down the rabbit hole, expecting to find a curious adventure, but instead, she found herself in a place where nothing made sense. The trees whispered secrets she could not hear, and the flowers sang songs she could not comprehend. She wandered through the strange landscape, her heart pounding with a mixture of fear and excitement.

As she walked, she came upon a small door, barely large enough for her to pass through. She tried the handle, but it was locked tight. Nearby, she noticed a key lying on a glass table. She picked it up and tried it in the lock, but it was too large. Frustrated, she looked around and saw a bottle labeled "Drink Me." Without hesitation, she took a sip. Suddenly, she began to shrink until she was small enough to fit through the door.

On the other side, Alice found herself in a beautiful garden filled with bright flowers and singing birds. She felt a sense of wonder and joy, but her adventure was far from over. She soon encountered a caterpillar sitting on a mushroom, smoking a hookah. The caterpillar asked her, "Who are you?" Alice was taken aback by the question and struggled to answer. She realized that in this strange land, identity was fluid and ever-changing.

The caterpillar gave her advice on how to change her size by eating different parts of the mushroom. Alice experimented, growing taller and shorter, trying to find the right size to continue her journey. As she explored further, she met the Cheshire Cat, who appeared and disappeared at will, leaving only his grin behind. The cat spoke in riddles and told Alice that everyone in Wonderland was mad, including herself.

Alice's path led her to a tea party hosted by the Mad Hatter, the March Hare, and the Dormouse. The tea party was chaotic, with nonsensical conversations and strange riddles. Alice tried to make sense of it all but found herself growing more confused. She realized that logic did not apply in Wonderland, and she would have to embrace the madness to find her way.

Continuing her journey, Alice came upon the Queen of Hearts' garden, where the Queen was playing croquet with flamingos as mallets and hedgehogs as balls. The Queen was quick to anger, shouting "Off with their heads!" at anyone who displeased her. Alice stood up to the Queen, refusing to be intimidated by her threats.

As the trial of the Knave of Hearts unfolded, Alice found herself growing larger and more confident. She challenged the absurdity of the proceedings and declared that the court was nothing but a pack of cards. Suddenly, the cards rose up and flew at her, and Alice woke up to find herself back on the riverbank, the adventure having been a curious dream.

Though puzzled and bewildered, Alice felt a newfound sense of courage and curiosity. She realized that the world was full of wonders and that sometimes, one had to embrace the unexpected to truly understand oneself.

events.title: The Dormouse's Story of the Treacle-Well Begins
detailed_summary: Alice inquires about what happens when they circle back to the start of the table.
The March Hare interrupts, changing the subject due to boredom and suggesting Alice tell a story.
Alice declines, feeling unprepared.
The March Hare and Hatter decide the Dormouse must tell a story and wake it by pinching.
The Dormouse, denying it was asleep, agrees to tell a story.
The Hatter urges it to be quick.
The Dormouse begins a story about three sisters (Elsie, Lacie, Tillie) living at the bottom of a well.
Alice interrupts, asking what they ate.
The Dormouse replies, after some thought, that they lived on treacle.
Alice gently objects that this would make them ill.
The Dormouse confirms they were indeed very ill.
Puzzled, Alice asks why they lived at the bottom of a well.
The March Hare interrupts again, earnestly offering Alice more tea.
Alice, offended, states she can't take *more* tea as she hasn't had any yet.
The Hatter corrects her, saying she means she can't take *less*, as taking more than nothing is easy.
Alice tells the Hatter his opinion wasn't requested.
The Hatter retorts, asking who is making personal remarks now.
Unsure how to respond, Alice takes some tea and bread-and-butter.
She repeats her question to the Dormouse about why the sisters lived in a well.
The Dormouse replies, after thinking, that it was a treacle-well.
Alice angrily starts to deny the existence of treacle-wells, but is shushed by the Hatter and March Hare.
The Dormouse sulkily suggests Alice finish the story herself if she can't be civil.
Alice humbly apologizes and asks the Dormouse to continue, conceding that perhaps one treacle-well exists.
The Dormouse expresses indignation at the suggestion there might be only one.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But what happens when you come to the beginning again?” Alice ventured to ask.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “One, indeed!” said the Dormouse indignantly.

events.text_segment:
“But what happens when you come to the beginning again?” Alice ventured to ask.
“Suppose we change the subject,” the March Hare interrupted, yawning. “I’m getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.”
“I’m afraid I don’t know one,” said Alice, rather alarmed at the proposal.
“Then the Dormouse shall!” they both cried. “Wake up, Dormouse!” And they pinched it on both sides at once.
The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. “I wasn’t asleep,” he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: “I heard every word you fellows were saying.”
“Tell us a story!” said the March Hare.
“Yes, please do!” pleaded Alice.
“And be quick about it,” added the Hatter, “or you’ll be asleep again before it’s done.”
“Once upon a time there were three little sisters,” the Dormouse began in a great hurry; “and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and they lived at the bottom of a well—”
“What did they live on?” said Alice, who always took a great interest in questions of eating and drinking.
“They lived on treacle,” said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or two.
“They couldn’t have done that, you know,” Alice gently remarked; “they’d have been ill.”
“So they were,” said the Dormouse; “very ill.”
Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: “But why did they live at the bottom of a well?”
“Take some more tea,” the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.
“I’ve had nothing yet,” Alice replied in an offended tone, “so I can’t take more.”
“You mean you can’t take less,” said the Hatter: “it’s very easy to take more than nothing.”
“Nobody asked your opinion,” said Alice.
“Who’s making personal remarks now?” the Hatter asked triumphantly.
Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and repeated her question. “Why did they live at the bottom of a well?”
The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then said, “It was a treacle-well.”
“There’s no such thing!” Alice was beginning very angrily, but the Hatter and the March Hare went “Sh! sh!” and the Dormouse sulkily remarked, “If you can’t be civil, you’d better finish the story for yourself.”
“No, please go on!” Alice said very humbly; “I won’t interrupt again. I dare say there may be one.”
“One, indeed!” said the Dormouse indignantly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"But what happens when you come to the beginning again?" Alice ventured to ask.

"Suppose we change the subject," the March Hare interrupted, yawning. "I'm getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story."

"I'm afraid I don't know one," said Alice, rather alarmed at the proposal.

"Then the Dormouse shall!" they both cried. "Wake up, Dormouse!"

But the Dormouse was fast asleep, and they pinched it on both sides at once.

The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. "I wasn't asleep," he said in a hoarse, feeble voice.

"Well, it's the stupidest thing I ever heard," said the March Hare, "to tell you the truth."

"Hold your tongue!" said the Hatter, turning to Alice, "You're thinking about something, and it makes you forget to talk."

"No, I was just wondering," said Alice.

"Then you should say what you wonder," the March Hare went on.

"I was wondering," Alice began, "why a raven is like a writing-desk?"

"Come, we shall have some fun now!" the March Hare said to the Hatter. "I'm glad they've begun asking riddles."

"I believe I can guess that," said Alice.

"Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?" said the Hatter.

"Exactly so," said Alice.

"Then you should say what you mean," the March Hare went on.

"I do," Alice hastily replied; "at least--at least I mean what I say--that's the same thing, you know."

"Not the same thing a bit!" said the Hatter. "You might just as well say that 'I see what I eat' is the same thing as 'I eat what I see'!"

"You might just as well say," added the March Hare, "that 'I like what I get' is the same thing as 'I get what I like'!"

"You might just as well say," added the Dormouse, who seemed to be talking in his sleep, "that 'I breathe when I sleep' is the same thing as 'I sleep when I breathe'!"

"It is the same thing with you," said the Hatter, and here the conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn't much.

"Have you guessed the riddle yet?" the Hatter said, turning to Alice again.

"No, I give it up," Alice replied: "what's the answer?"

"I haven't the slightest idea," said the Hatter.

"Nor I," said the March Hare.

Alice sighed wearily. "I think you might do something better with the time," she said, "than wasting it in asking riddles that have no answers."

"If you knew Time as well as I do," said the Hatter, "you wouldn't talk about wasting it. It's him."

"I don't know what you mean," said Alice.

"Of course you don't!" the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously. "I dare say you never even spoke to Time!"

"Perhaps not," Alice cautiously replied: "but I know I have to beat time when I learn music."

"Ah! that accounts for it," said the Hatter. "He won't stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he'd do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o'clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you'd only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!"

("I only wish it was," the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)

"That would be grand, certainly," said Alice thoughtfully: "but then--I shouldn't be hungry for it, you know."

"Not at first, perhaps," said the Hatter: "but you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked."

"Is that the way you manage?" Alice asked.

The Hatter shook his head mournfully. "Not I!" he replied. "We quarreled last March--just before he went mad, you know--" (pointing with his tea spoon at the March Hare) "--it was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing

"Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
How I wonder what you're at!"

You know the song, perhaps?"

"I've heard something like it," said Alice.

"It goes on, you know," the Hatter continued, "in this way:--

Up above the world you fly,
Like a tea-tray in the sky.

That's the song, I think."

"I've heard something like it," said Alice.

"It must be the same," said the Hatter, "or very like it."

"Come, let's have some tea," the March Hare said to Alice.

"Yes, please," said Alice.

They all sat down at the table, and the March Hare began pouring out the tea.

"Have some more tea," the March Hare said to Alice.

"I haven't had any yet," Alice replied in an offended tone.

"You mean you can't take less," said the Hatter: "it's very easy to take more than nothing."

"Nobody asked your opinion," said Alice.

"Who is making personal remarks now?" the Hatter asked triumphantly.

"Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" Alice repeated, half to herself.

"Come, we shall have some fun now!" the March Hare said to the Hatter. "I'm glad they've begun asking riddles."

"I believe I can guess that," said Alice.

"Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?" said the Hatter.

"Exactly so," said Alice.

"Then you should say what you mean," the March Hare went on.

"I do," Alice hastily replied; "at least--at least I mean what I say

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“But what happens when you come to the beginning again?” Alice ventured to ask.

“Why, then you begin again, of course,” said the White Rabbit, glancing nervously over his shoulder as he hurried along.

Alice pondered this for a moment. “But if you keep beginning again, do you ever get anywhere?”

The Rabbit stopped and looked at her with a curious expression. “That depends on what you mean by ‘anywhere.’ Sometimes the journey is the destination.”

Alice frowned. “That sounds rather confusing.”

“Indeed,” said the Rabbit, “but in Wonderland, confusion is often the clearest path.”

As they walked, the trees around them began to twist and shimmer, their branches forming intricate patterns that seemed to dance in the dappled sunlight.

“Look!” exclaimed Alice. “The trees are moving!”

“Only to those who know how to see,” replied the Rabbit. “In Wonderland, things are not always as they seem.”

They came upon a clearing where a large caterpillar sat atop a mushroom, smoking a hookah. He eyed Alice with a slow, deliberate gaze.

“Who are you?” he asked in a deep, measured voice.

“I’m Alice,” she replied. “I’m trying to understand this place.”

The caterpillar nodded thoughtfully. “Understanding is a journey, not a destination. You must learn to ask the right questions.”

“What questions should I ask?” Alice inquired.

“Questions that challenge your assumptions,” he said. “For instance, what is the beginning? What is the end? And what lies between?”

Alice considered this. “But if the beginning and end are the same, does that mean the journey is endless?”

“Perhaps,” said the caterpillar. “Or perhaps it is a circle, and circles have no end.”

Alice looked around, noticing the circular patterns in the clearing, the way the flowers seemed to form rings.

“Then maybe I’m already where I need to be,” she mused.

The caterpillar smiled. “Sometimes, the answer is simpler than you think.”

As Alice continued on her way, she felt a newfound sense of calm. The confusion of Wonderland was beginning to make sense, not through logic, but through acceptance.

She realized that in this strange land, the rules were different, and that was okay. The journey, with all its twists and turns, was part of the adventure.

And so, with a light heart, Alice stepped forward, ready to embrace whatever came next, knowing that every beginning was also an end, and every end a new beginning.

events.title: The Nonsensical Story Continues, the Party Shifts, and Alice Departs
detailed_summary: The Dormouse agrees to continue the story about the three sisters learning to draw.
Alice, forgetting her promise not to interrupt, asks what they drew.
The Dormouse instantly replies, "Treacle."
The Hatter interrupts, wanting a clean cup and initiating a move one place along the table.
Everyone shifts: Dormouse follows Hatter, March Hare takes Dormouse's place, Alice unwillingly takes March Hare's (recently dirtied) place.
Only the Hatter benefits from the change.
Alice cautiously asks the Dormouse where the treacle was drawn from.

events.text_segment:
However, he consented to go on. “And so these three little sisters—they were learning to draw, you know—”
“What did they draw?” said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.
“Treacle,” said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.
“I want a clean cup,” interrupted the Hatter: “let’s all move one place on.”
He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare moved into the Dormouse’s place, and Alice rather unwillingly took the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.
Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: “But I don’t understand. Where did they draw the treacle from?”
“You can draw water out of a water-well,” said the Hatter; “so I should think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well—eh, stupid?”
“But they were in the well,” Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to notice this last remark.
“Of course they were,” said the Dormouse; “—well in.”
This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for some time without interrupting it.
“They were learning to draw,” the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; “and they drew all manner of things—everything that begins with an M—”
“Why with an M?” said Alice.
“Why not?” said the March Hare.
Alice was silent.
The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on: “—that begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say things are “much of a muchness”—did you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?”
“Really, now you ask me,” said Alice, very much confused, “I don’t think—”
“Then you shouldn’t talk,” said the Hatter.
This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her: the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.

"You don't know what 'muchness' is?" said the Hatter. Alice shook her head sadly. "Try," the March Hare said, "why, I can tell you—" "No, no," said the Hatter. "The Dormouse is asleep again." When the Dormouse had shut its eyes and had made a long yawn, they began moving about again, and Alice went back to her own place, the March Hare following her. "Take some more tea," the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly. "I've had nothing yet," Alice replied in an offended tone, "so I can't take more." "You mean you can't take less," said the Hatter: "it's very easy to take more than nothing." "Nobody asked your opinion," said Alice. "Who’s making personal remarks now?" the Hatter asked triumphantly. Alice did not quite like the tone of this remark, and thought it would be as well to say nothing. "Have some wine," the March Hare said. Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea. "I don't see any wine," she remarked. "There isn't any," said the March Hare. "Then it wasn't very civil of you to offer it," said Alice angrily. "It wasn't very civil of you to sit down without being invited," said the March Hare. Alice didn't know what to say to this: so she helped herself to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and repeated her question. "What did they draw?" The Dormouse replied instantly, "Treacle." "I want a clean cup," interrupted the Hatter: he moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare moved into the Dormouse's place, and Alice rather unwillingly took the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any advantage from the change; and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate. Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: "But I don't understand. Where did they draw the treacle from?" "You can draw water out of a water-well," said the Hatter; "so I should think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well—eh, stupid?" "But they were in the well," Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to notice this last remark. "Of course they were," said the Dormouse; "—well in." This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for some time without interrupting it. "They were learning to draw," the Dormouse went on dreamily, "and they drew all manner of things—everything that begins with an M—" "Why with an M?" said Alice. "Why not?" said the March Hare. Alice was silent. The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on: "—that begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say things are 'much of a muchness'?" "You don't know what 'muchness' is?" said the Hatter. Alice shook her head sadly. "Try," the March Hare said, "why, I can tell you—" "No, no," said the Hatter. "The Dormouse is asleep again." This time Alice waited patiently until the Dormouse woke up. But the Hatter and the March Hare were too much engaged in trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot to notice her departure. Alice got up and walked away from the table in disgust.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
However, he consented to go on. Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, 'and what is the use of a book,' thought Alice 'without pictures or conversation?'

So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chains would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.

There was nothing so very remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, 'Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!' (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge.

In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.

The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.

Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs.

She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labeled 'ORANGE MARMALADE', but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.

'Well!' thought Alice to herself, 'after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they'll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn't say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!'

Down, down, down. Would the fall never come to an end! 'I wonder how many miles I've fallen by this time?' she said aloud. 'I must be getting somewhere near the center of the earth. Let me see: that would be four thousand miles down, I think—' (for, you see, Alice had learnt several things of this sort in her lessons in the schoolroom, and though this was not a very good opportunity for showing off her knowledge, as there was no one to listen to her, still it was good practice to say it over) '—yes, that's about the right distance—but then I wonder what Latitude or Longitude I've got to?' (Alice had no idea what Latitude was, or Longitude either, but thought they were nice grand words to say.)

Presently she began again. 'I wonder if I shall fall right through the earth! How funny it'll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward! The Antipathies, I think—' (she was rather glad there was no one listening, this time, as it didn't sound at all the right word) '—but I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know. Please, Ma'am, is this New Zealand or Australia?' (and she tried to curtsey as she spoke—fancy curtseying as you're falling through the air! Do you think you could manage it?)

'And what an ignorant little girl she'll think me for asking! No, it'll never do to ask: perhaps I shall see it written up somewhere.'

events.title: Alice Leaves the Tea Party and Discovers a Door in a Tree
detailed_summary: Walking through the woods, Alice resolves never to return to the tea party, calling it the stupidest she ever attended.
She notices a tree with a door leading directly into it.
Finding it curious, but accepting the general strangeness of the day, she decides to enter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At any rate I’ll never go there again!” said Alice as she picked her way through the wood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And in she went.

events.text_segment:
“At any rate I’ll never go there again!” said Alice as she picked her way through the wood. “It’s the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all my life!”
Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it. “That’s very curious!” she thought. “But everything’s curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.” And in she went.

events.title: Alice Returns to the Hall and Finally Enters the Garden
detailed_summary: Alice finds herself back in the familiar long hall near the glass table.
Confident she can manage better this time, she takes the golden key.
She unlocks the small door leading to the garden.
Using the piece of mushroom she saved, she adjusts her height until she is about twelve inches tall.
She walks through the little passage.
Finally, Alice successfully enters the beautiful garden she had longed to reach.

events.text_segment: Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little glass table. “Now, I’ll manage better this time,” she said to herself, and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and then—she found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.

events.title: Gardeners Painting Roses
detailed_summary: Alice observed three gardeners painting white roses red on a large rose tree near the garden entrance.
She overheard them arguing, with Five blaming Seven for jogging his elbow and splashing paint.
Seven accused Five of blaming others, and Five retorted that the Queen wanted Seven beheaded for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.
Seven started to protest the injustice but stopped abruptly upon noticing Alice watching.
All three gardeners bowed low to Alice.
Alice timidly asked why they were painting the roses.
Two explained, prompted by the silence of Five and Seven, that they had mistakenly planted a white rose tree instead of a red one.
He elaborated that they feared the Queen would have them all beheaded if she discovered the mistake.
They were hastily trying to paint the roses red before the Queen's arrival.
Suddenly, Five shouted a warning that the Queen was coming, and the three gardeners immediately prostrated themselves on the ground.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red.

events.text_segment:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, “Look out now, Five! Don’t go splashing paint over me like that!”
“I couldn’t help it,” said Five, in a sulky tone; “Seven jogged my elbow.”
On which Seven looked up and said, “That’s right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!”
“You’d better not talk!” said Five. “I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!”
“What for?” said the one who had spoken first.
“That’s none of your business, Two!” said Seven.
“Yes, it is his business!” said Five, “and I’ll tell him—it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.”
Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun “Well, of all the unjust things—” when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.
“Would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, “why you are painting those roses?”
Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low voice, “Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a red rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know. So you see, Miss, we’re doing our best, afore she comes, to—” At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out “The Queen! The Queen!” and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of the gardeners say, "Look out now, Five! Don't go splashing paint over me like that!"

"I couldn't help it," said Five, in a sulky tone; "Seven jogged me."

On which Seven looked up and said, "That's right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!"

"You'd better not talk!" said Five. "I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!"

"What for?"

"That's none of my business, you know!"

The Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting "Off with his head! Off with his head!" but the poor little gardener called Five, and the others, went very pale and shaky, and looked as if they would run away.

Alice thought to herself, "If they had any sense, they'd run away too!"

Just then the Queen noticed Alice, and said, "Who is this?"

"She is a child," said the King.

"Get her to play croquet," said the Queen.

Alice was glad to get into the game, though she had never played croquet before. The mallets were live flamingos, and the balls were hedgehogs. The players had to run after the hedgehogs, and the flamingos kept turning their heads and knocking the balls away.

It was a very difficult game, and Alice soon found herself in the middle of a great deal of confusion. The Queen was shouting "Off with his head!" at every opportunity, and the other players were running about in a panic.

Alice did her best to play, but the game was so strange and disorderly that she could hardly keep up. She thought to herself, "This is the most curious game I have ever played!"

events.title: The Royal Procession Arrives
detailed_summary: A procession began, led by ten club-carrying soldiers shaped like playing cards.
Following them were ten courtiers adorned with diamonds, walking in pairs.
Next came ten royal children, decorated with hearts, skipping hand-in-hand in couples.
A group of guests, mainly Kings and Queens, followed, among whom Alice spotted the White Rabbit.
The White Rabbit appeared nervous, smiled at everything, and passed by Alice without recognizing her.
The Knave of Hearts followed, carrying the King's crown on a cushion.
Finally, the King and Queen of Hearts appeared at the end of the grand procession.
Alice considered lying face down like the gardeners but decided against it, reasoning that processions were meant to be seen.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So she stood still where she was, and waited.

events.text_segment:
First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions; “and besides, what would be the use of a procession,” thought she, “if people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn’t see it?” So she stood still where she was, and waited.

After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and they all wore hearts. They walked in couples, the two little girls holding hands: the little boys skipped by them hand in hand. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice could see the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand and a scroll of parchment in the other. He looked rather anxiously about, and seemed to be in a hurry; but he smiled and waved his hand to Alice, as if he had not noticed her, and passed on. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and last of all this grand procession came the King and Queen of Hearts.

Alice thought to herself, "What a curious feeling! I must be shutting my eyes; but I am not! I must be lying on my face like the gardeners, and if I do, the Queen will be quite sure to notice me. I think I shall lie down on my side, and see what happens." But then she remembered that processions were made to be seen, and she sat up again.

The procession moved slowly towards the garden, where the Queen was to play croquet with her guests. Alice followed, wondering what adventures awaited her next in this curious land.

events.title: Alice Confronts the Queen
detailed_summary: The entire procession halted upon reaching Alice.
The Queen sternly asked the Knave of Hearts to identify Alice, but the Knave only bowed and smiled.
The Queen impatiently called the Knave an idiot and turned to Alice, demanding her name.
Alice politely introduced herself as Alice but privately reminded herself that they were merely a pack of cards and she shouldn't be afraid.
The Queen then pointed to the prostrate gardeners and asked Alice who they were, unable to identify them due to their face-down position and card-like appearance.
Alice, surprising herself with her boldness, replied that it was none of her business.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It’s no business of mine.”

events.text_segment:
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?” She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
“Idiot!” said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, “What’s your name, child?”
“My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,” said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, “Why, they’re only a pack of cards, after all. I needn’t be afraid of them!”
“And who are these?” said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
“How should I know?” said Alice, surprised at her own courage. “It’s no business of mine.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely, "Who is this?"

"She is the most curious child!" said the King.

The Queen said to the Knave of Hearts, "Turn them over!"

The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.

"Get up!" said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, and everybody else.

"Leave out that," the Queen said to the Knave, "and don’t be all day about it!"

They were playing at croquet now, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.

Alice thought the whole thing very confusing, and she looked round, hoping to find her way back to the house; but the house was gone, and the garden was gone, and the Queen was close behind her, and she was saying, "Who is this?"

The Knave of Hearts only bowed and smiled in reply.

"Idiot!" said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, "What’s your name, child?"

"My name is Alice," said Alice politely; but she added, to herself, "Why, they’re only a pack of cards! I needn’t be afraid of them!"

"And who are those?" said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rosetree, with their hands and feet in the air, just like the other three gardeners.

"It’s no business of mine," said Alice.

events.title: Gardeners Saved, Croquet Invitation Issued
detailed_summary: The Queen became enraged at Alice's response and furiously ordered her execution.
Alice loudly and firmly dismissed the order as nonsense, which silenced the Queen.
The King gently intervened, reminding the Queen that Alice was only a child.
The Queen angrily turned away from the King and ordered the Knave to turn the gardeners over.
The Knave carefully flipped the gardeners using his foot.
The Queen commanded the gardeners to get up, and they immediately did, bowing profusely to everyone.
The Queen yelled at them to stop bowing as it made her dizzy.
Turning to the rose tree, she demanded to know what the gardeners had been doing.
Two humbly began to explain, kneeling, that they were trying to fix their mistake.
The Queen, having examined the roses, cut him off, declared "Off with their heads!", and the procession started moving again.
Three soldiers stayed behind to execute the gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
Alice declared they wouldn't be beheaded and hid them in a large, nearby flower-pot.
The soldiers searched briefly, failed to find the gardeners, and marched off after the procession.
The Queen shouted from a distance, asking if the gardeners' heads were off.
The soldiers shouted back that their heads were gone.
Satisfied, the Queen shouted back, asking if Alice could play croquet.
The soldiers looked expectantly at Alice, who confirmed she could play.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yes!” shouted Alice.

events.text_segment:
The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—”
“Nonsense!” said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said “Consider, my dear: she is only a child!”
The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave “Turn them over!”
The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
“Get up!” said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.
“Leave off that!” screamed the Queen. “You make me giddy.” And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, “What have you been doing here?”
“May it please your Majesty,” said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, “we were trying—”
“I see!” said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses. “Off with their heads!” and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
“You shan’t be beheaded!” said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.
“Are their heads off?” shouted the Queen.
“Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!” the soldiers shouted in reply.
“That’s right!” shouted the Queen. “Can you play croquet?”
The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
“Yes!” shouted Alice.

events.title: Joining the Procession and Learning the Duchess's Fate
detailed_summary: The Queen roared for Alice to join them, and Alice entered the procession, curious about future events.
A timid voice beside her commented on the fine day; it was the White Rabbit, looking anxiously at her.
Alice agreed and asked about the Duchess's location.
The Rabbit urgently hushed her, looking around nervously.
He whispered closely to Alice that the Duchess was under sentence of execution.
Alice asked what the Duchess had done.
The Rabbit misheard, asking if Alice had said 'What a pity!'.
Alice clarified she didn't think it was a pity and repeated her question about the reason for the sentence.
The Rabbit began explaining that the Duchess had boxed the Queen's ears.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Come on, then!” roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “She boxed the Queen’s ears—” the Rabbit began.

events.text_segment:
“Come on, then!” roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.
“It’s—it’s a very fine day!” said a timid voice at her side. She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
“Very,” said Alice: “—where’s the Duchess?”
“Hush! Hush!” said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered “She’s under sentence of execution.”
“What for?” said Alice.
“Did you say ‘What a pity!’?” the Rabbit asked.
“No, I didn’t,” said Alice: “I don’t think it’s at all a pity. I said ‘What for?’”
“She boxed the Queen’s ears—” the Rabbit began.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Come on, then!" roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.

The procession was headed by the Queen, who was followed by the King, the Knave of Hearts, and a great crowd of courtiers, soldiers, and heralds. Alice noticed a timid little voice beside her, and looking down, she saw the White Rabbit, who was glancing anxiously up and down, and whispering to himself.

"What a fine day!" said the Rabbit, in a low voice.

"Yes," said Alice, "it's a very fine day. But where is the Duchess?"

The Rabbit looked nervously all around, and then leaned close to Alice and whispered, "She's under sentence of execution."

"What for?" asked Alice.

The Rabbit misheard her and said, "What a pity!"

"I didn't say that," Alice explained. "I want to know what she has done to be sentenced."

"She boxed the Queen's ears," said the Rabbit.

events.title: The Absurdities of the Royal Croquet Game
detailed_summary: Alice couldn't help laughing at the idea of the Duchess boxing the Queen's ears.
The Rabbit frantically hushed her again, afraid the Queen would overhear, mentioning the Duchess had arrived late.
The Queen's thundering voice interrupted, ordering everyone to their places for croquet.
A chaotic scramble ensued as people rushed and bumped into each other before settling down.
The game began on what Alice considered a bizarre croquet ground, full of ridges and furrows.
Living hedgehogs were used as balls, live flamingoes served as mallets, and soldiers bent over to form the arches.
Alice initially struggled to manage her flamingo mallet; its body could be tucked under her arm, but its neck would often twist around to look at her just as she was about to strike the hedgehog.
Her laughter at the flamingo's puzzled expression caused delays.
When she managed to position the flamingo, the hedgehog ball would often unroll and crawl away.
Obstacles like ridges, furrows, and wandering soldier-arches added to the difficulty.
Alice quickly realized the game was exceedingly challenging.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Alice gave a little scream of laughter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

events.text_segment:
Alice gave a little scream of laughter. “Oh, hush!” the Rabbit whispered in a frightened tone. “The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said—”
“Get to your places!” shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.
The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it would twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

Hush! You'll be getting us all into trouble! The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said—' 'Get to your places!' shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began.

Alice thought the whole thing very confusing. The croquet-ground was a large, flat space, but it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.

Alice was not a little surprised to find that she was the only player on her side: the others were all on the Queen's side, and that the Queen herself was the other player. The first thing she did was to try and get her flamingo to stand still, but it would not do so, and kept turning its head all round, and looking at her with one eye, as if it thought it was a very funny thing to do.

Alice was quite unable to manage her flamingo, and the hedgehogs were getting away from her in all directions. The soldiers were running about, and the arches were moving, and the Queen was shouting 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!' about once in a minute.

Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Alice gave a little scream of laughter. "Oh, you can't help that," said the Cat: "we're all mad here. I'm mad. You're mad." "How do you know I'm mad?" said Alice. "You must be," said the Cat, "or you wouldn't have come here." Alice didn't think that proved it at all; however, she went on, "And how do you know that you're mad?" "To begin with," said the Cat, "a dog's not mad. You grant that?" "I suppose so," said Alice. "Well, then," the Cat went on, "you see, a dog growls when it's angry, and wags its tail when it's pleased. Now I growl when I'm pleased, and wag my tail when I'm angry. Therefore I'm mad." "I call it purring, not growling," said Alice. "Call it what you like," said the Cat. "Do you play croquet with the Queen to-day?" "I should like it very much," said Alice, "but I haven't been invited yet." "You'll see me there," said the Cat, and vanished. Alice was not much surprised at this, she had often seen a cat without a grin before, but a grin without a cat! It's the most curious thing she ever saw in her life. She had not gone much farther before she came upon the Queen's gardeners, who were painting the roses red. "Why are you painting those roses?" Alice asked. "Why, the Queen ordered it," said one of the gardeners. "I didn't know that roses could be white," Alice remarked. "Oh, they can," said the other; "and that's why we have to paint them red."

events.title: Conversation with the Cheshire Cat
detailed_summary: All players played simultaneously, ignoring turns, constantly arguing, and fighting over the hedgehogs.
The Queen quickly became enraged, stomping around and frequently shouting orders for beheadings.
Alice grew uneasy, realizing that although she hadn't argued with the Queen yet, it could happen anytime, making her wonder about her own fate given the prevalence of executions.
She started looking for an escape route.
While contemplating escape, Alice noticed a peculiar shape materializing in the air.
After observing it, she recognized it as a grin and identified it as the Cheshire Cat, feeling pleased she would have someone to talk to.
The Cat asked Alice how she was doing as soon as its mouth appeared.
Alice waited for its eyes to appear before nodding, thinking it pointless to speak until its ears materialized.
Once the Cat's entire head was visible, Alice put down her flamingo and began describing the game, glad for a listener.
Only the Cat's head became visible; the rest of its body did not appear.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

events.text_segment:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, “and then,” thought she, “what would become of me? They’re dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there’s any one left alive!”
She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself “It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.”
“How are you getting on?” said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. “It’s no use speaking to it,” she thought, “till its ears have come, or at least one of them.” In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.

Alice began to feel very uneasy; to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, and then, thought she, what would become of me? As for the other players, they were all in a dreadful state of anxiety, and there was a general clamor of voices, all talking at once, and no one attending to what anyone else said.

Alice looked round, eager to find some way of escape, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air. At first it was only a grin, and then the grin became gradually more distinct, until at last it formed into the well-known face of the Cheshire Cat.

"How are you getting on now?" said the Cat, as soon as its mouth appeared.

Alice waited till its eyes appeared, and then nodded. She thought it would be no use speaking till its ears had come, so she held her tongue.

When the Cat's whole head had appeared, she put down her flamingo, and began to tell it the history of the game, feeling very glad to have someone to listen to her.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.

Alice began to feel very uneasy. To be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, and then, thought she, what would become of me? She was just looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get out without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air.

At first it seemed to be only a grin, and after watching it for a minute or two, it appeared to Alice to be the smile of the Cheshire Cat. "Well!" thought Alice to herself, "after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they'll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn't say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!"

The Cat's mouth opened wide, and then its eyes appeared. "How are you getting on now?" said the Cat.

Alice waited till its ears appeared, and then she nodded. She thought it would be no use speaking till its ears had come.

When the Cat's whole head had appeared, she put down her flamingo, and began to tell it the history of the game, feeling very glad to have someone to talk to.

But the rest of the Cat's body did not appear.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and begged her to moderate her fury, and said he was sure there was no necessity for any executions; and after a moment’s hesitation, the Queen turned to Alice, and said, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”

“No,” said Alice.

“Come on, then,” said the Queen, “or you’ll be off your head.”

Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought to go, but the Duchess had given her no warning, and she thought it would be as well to keep the Queen in good temper, as long as possible, and she went with her.

They went on, through a beautiful wood, and Alice thought she had never seen such a curious place before. The trees were all alive, and the flowers were talking to each other, and the birds were singing the most extraordinary songs.

At last they came to a little house, all made of sugar, and the windows were made of clear candy. The Queen knocked at the door, and a voice called out, “Who’s there?”

“It’s me, the Queen of Hearts,” said the Queen.

The door opened, and a strange creature came out. It had the head of a calf, the body of a turtle, and the tail of a fish.

“This is the Mock Turtle,” said the Queen. “He’s very sad, because he’s lost his voice.”

Alice felt sorry for him, and asked what had happened.

events.title: Royal Displeasure and Sentence for the Cheshire Cat
detailed_summary: Alice complained to the Cheshire Cat about the unfairness and chaos of the croquet game.
She highlighted the constant quarreling, lack of apparent rules, and confusion caused by the living game pieces like wandering arches and fleeing hedgehogs.
The Cat quietly asked Alice for her opinion of the Queen.
Alice started to express her dislike but noticed the Queen listening nearby.
She quickly modified her sentence to say the Queen was so likely to win that finishing the game seemed pointless.
The Queen smiled at this remark and moved on.
The King approached Alice, asking who she was talking to and observing the Cat's head with curiosity.
Alice introduced the Cat as her friend.
The King expressed his dislike for the Cat's appearance but permitted it to kiss his hand.
The Cat declined the offer.
The King admonished the Cat for impertinence and its stare, hiding behind Alice.
Alice remarked that she'd read somewhere that a cat may look at a king.
The King firmly declared the Cat must be removed and called the Queen over.
He requested that the Queen have the Cat removed.
The Queen, without hesitation or looking, issued her standard solution: "Off with his head!"
The King eagerly volunteered to fetch the executioner himself and rushed away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

events.text_segment:
“I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
“How do you like the Queen?” said the Cat in a low voice.
“Not at all,” said Alice: “she’s so extremely—” Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, “—likely to win, that it’s hardly worth while finishing the game.”
The Queen smiled and passed on.
“Who are you talking to?” said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat’s head with great curiosity.
“It’s a friend of mine—a Cheshire Cat,” said Alice: “allow me to introduce it.”
“I don’t like the look of it at all,” said the King: “however, it may kiss my hand if it likes.”
“I’d rather not,” the Cat remarked.
“Don’t be impertinent,” said the King, “and don’t look at me like that!” He got behind Alice as he spoke.
“A cat may look at a king,” said Alice. “I’ve read that in some book, but I don’t remember where.”
“Well, it must be removed,” said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, “My dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!”
The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. “Off with his head!” she said, without even looking round.
“I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—” “Nonsense!” said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent. events.title: Croquet Chaos and the Executioner's Conundrum
detailed_summary: Hearing the Queen shouting angrily in the distance, Alice decided to check on the croquet game.
She had already heard the Queen sentence three players to execution for missing turns and felt uneasy about the general confusion, which made it hard to know whose turn it was.
Alice went searching for her hedgehog ball.
She found her hedgehog fighting another one, which seemed like a good croquet opportunity.
However, her flamingo mallet had wandered to the other side of the garden and was attempting to fly into a tree.
By the time Alice retrieved the flamingo, the hedgehog fight was over, and both hedgehogs were gone.
Alice noted resignedly that the arches on her side of the ground were also gone.
She tucked the flamingo under her arm to prevent another escape and went back to talk to the Cheshire Cat.
Upon returning, Alice found a large crowd gathered around the Cat's location.
An argument was in progress between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, all talking simultaneously, while everyone else looked uncomfortable and remained silent.
Alice was immediately asked by all three to settle the dispute.
They repeated their arguments, though Alice struggled to understand them as they all spoke at once.
The executioner argued he couldn't behead something without a body, stating he'd never done it before and wouldn't start now.
The King argued that anything with a head could be beheaded and dismissed the executioner's point as nonsense.
The Queen argued that if the issue wasn't resolved instantly, she would have everyone executed, which caused widespread anxiety.
Alice suggested asking the Duchess about the Cat, as it belonged to her.
The Queen ordered the executioner to fetch the Duchess from prison.
The executioner dashed off.
As soon as the executioner left, the Cheshire Cat's head began to fade.
By the time the executioner returned with the Duchess, the Cat's head had vanished completely.
The King and executioner searched frantically for the disappeared head, while the rest of the attendees returned to the croquet game.

events.text_segment:
Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.
The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: “but it doesn’t matter much,” thought Alice, “as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.” So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.
When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.
The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at his time of life.
The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.
The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time she’d have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
Alice could think of nothing else to say but “It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask her about it.”
“She’s in prison,” the Queen said to the executioner: “fetch her here.” And the executioner went off like an arrow.
The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

By the time she had caught it and brought it back, the fight was over, and both hedgehogs had disappeared. The arches on her side of the ground were also gone. She tucked the flamingo under her arm to prevent its escape and went back to the Cheshire Cat. When she returned, she found a large crowd gathered around the Cat's usual spot. The executioner, the King, and the Queen were all talking at once, while the rest of the crowd looked uncomfortable and silent. They all turned to Alice and asked her to settle their dispute. As soon as he left, the Cheshire Cat's head began to fade. By the time the executioner returned with the Duchess, the Cat's head had vanished completely. The King and executioner searched frantically for the missing head, while the rest of the crowd returned to the croquet game.
