Alice smiled. “Yes, and it taught me that sometimes, things don’t have to make sense to be wonderful.”

The Gryphon nodded. “Exactly. And that’s the magic of Wonderland.”

As the sun began to set, Alice felt a gentle tug. “It’s time to go back,” she said. “But I’ll never forget my adventures here.”

With a blink, she found herself back in her own world, carrying the memories of a day filled with wonder and whimsy.

events.text_segment:
That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
“Well, I never heard it before,” said the Mock Turtle; “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would ever happen in a natural way again.
“I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle.
“She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”
“But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted. “How could he turn them out with his nose, you know?”
“It’s the first position in dancing.” Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
“Go on with the next verse,” the Gryphon repeated impatiently: “it begins ‘I passed by his garden.’”
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—
“I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”

"Well, I never heard it before," said the Mock Turtle; "so I can't tell whether it's right or wrong."

"Don't be such a simpleton," said the Gryphon, and then they both sat silent, looking at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Mock Turtle said, "You may not have lived much under the sea—"

"I haven't," said Alice.

"And perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—"

"I once tasted—" Alice began, but checked herself hastily.

"I have seen a good many lobsters," continued the Mock Turtle, "but very few of them know any thing about quadrilles—"

"Are they quadrilles?" said Alice.

"Of course they are. Why, if you don't know what a quadrille is, you ought to learn."

"Is it like a dance?" asked Alice.

"Of course it is. It's a kind of dance you know."

"I know what a dance is," said Alice. "Do you mean the Lobster Quadrille?"

"Yes," said the Gryphon. "Come, let's hear some of it."

Alice trembled, but she began:—

'There's a porpoise close behind us, and he's treading on my tail.'"

When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!"

“When I was a child,” said the Gryphon, “I used to say, ‘Speak roughly to your little boy, and beat him when he sneaks.’ Now I only say, ‘Speak roughly to your little boy, and beat him when he sneaks,’ because it’s the same thing.”

Alice thought this a very curious way of putting things. “I don’t like the way you’re talking about children,” she said. “I don’t think it’s right to be rough to them.”

“Then you’re a simpleton,” said the Gryphon. “You don’t know what’s good for you.”

Just then, the Mock Turtle began to sing, “Beautiful Soup, so rich and green, Waiting in a hot tureen! Who for such dainties would not stoop? Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!”

Alice listened with delight, though she found the song rather sad. The Gryphon and the Mock Turtle danced and sang, telling tales of their school days under the sea, where lessons were taught by a sea turtle and the subjects included music, dancing, and the mysterious Lobster Quadrille.

events.title: Mock Turtle Sings 'Turtle Soup' Before Abrupt Departure
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle interrupts Alice's recitation again, questioning the point of repeating confusing material without explaining it.
He declares it the most confusing thing he has ever heard.
The Gryphon suggests Alice should stop reciting, and Alice is relieved to comply.

Her eagerness slightly offends the Gryphon, who comments on tastes and asks the Mock Turtle to sing 'Turtle Soup'.
The Mock Turtle sighs deeply and begins singing, his voice occasionally choked with sobs.
The song praises 'Beautiful Soup', describing it as rich, green, and waiting in a hot tureen.

The song continues, asking who cares for other dishes like fish or game when compared to Beautiful Soup.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?

events.text_segment:
“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!”
“Yes, I think you’d better leave off,” said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
“Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon went on. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”
“Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,” Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, “Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her ‘Turtle Soup,’ will you, old fellow?”
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—
“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
“Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
Game, or any other dish?
Who would not give all else for two p
ennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!”
“Chorus again!” cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of “The trial’s beginning!” was heard in the distance.
“Come on!” cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
“What trial is it?” Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered “Come on!” and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—
“Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

**Simulated Output:**

“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s the most confusing thing I ever heard!”

Alice looked up, a little startled. The Gryphon nodded in agreement. “Perhaps you’d better stop now,” he said. Alice was glad to do so.

“Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon suggested. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”

“Oh, please!” Alice exclaimed eagerly. “If the Mock Turtle would be so kind.”

The Gryphon gave a slight frown. “Tastes differ,” he remarked, “but I think you’ll find this one more to your liking.” Turning to the Mock Turtle, he said, “Sing ‘Turtle Soup,’ old fellow!”

The Mock Turtle sighed deeply and began in a voice choked with sobs:

“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!

“Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—vening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

The Gryphon clapped his wings. “Encore! Encore!” he cried. “Sing the chorus again!”

But just as the Mock Turtle opened his mouth to begin, a distant voice called out, “The trial’s beginning!”

“Come on!” shouted the Gryphon, grabbing Alice’s hand. Without waiting for the song to finish, they hurried away.

“Wait! What trial is it?” Alice panted as they ran.

“Come on!” the Gryphon urged, running faster.

Behind them, the sad refrain of the Mock Turtle’s song faded softly on the breeze.

“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s the most confusing thing I ever heard!”

“Do you like the Mock Turtle’s singing?” the Gryphon asked, with a slight frown.

“Oh, yes!” said Alice eagerly. “I’d like to hear some of the song, if you know it.”

“You might like to try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille,” said the Gryphon, “or else the Mock Turtle can sing you a song: ‘Turtle Soup,’ if you’d like that.”

“Oh, please! Sing it!” said Alice.

The Gryphon looked at her with a little offended air. “You’re all right, though,” he said, “and I’ll sing it if you like.”

The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began in a voice sometimes choked with sobs:

“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!

“Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—vening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!

“Who cares for fish, game, or any other dish?
Who would not give all else for just a small drop of this?
Beautiful Soup!

“Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—vening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

“Sing the chorus again!” cried the Gryphon.

“Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—vening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

But just as the Mock Turtle began to repeat it once more, a distant voice cried, “The trial’s beginning!”

“Come on!” shouted the Gryphon, taking Alice by the hand, and they hurried away without waiting for the song to finish.

“Wait! What trial is it?” Alice panted as they ran.

“Come on!” the Gryphon answered, running faster.

And the sad words of the Mock Turtle’s song, “Beautiful Soup,” were borne softly on the breeze behind them.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I’m afraid I can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon. “It’s done in a hurry, and you might not understand it.”

“That’s just the way I like it,” said Alice. “I can’t quite follow it as it is.”

“The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. “Same as if he had a bone in his throat,” said the Gryphon; and it set to shaking itself and its tail, and had to hiccup.

“Please don’t tease,” said Alice, “and don’t be angry with me. I want to hear all about it.”

“Well, as I was saying,” the Mock Turtle went on, “we used to live in the sea. The best place to live was in a little cave at the bottom, near a well. We’d have lessons every day, and the master was an old Turtle called Tortoise.”

“Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.

“We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily: “really you are very dull!”

“Once,” continued the Mock Turtle, “we had a lesson on the different branches of arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.”

“I never heard of ‘Uglification’ before,” Alice remarked.

“Of course you haven’t,” said the Mock Turtle, “it’s the branch of arithmetic you learn about in the sea.”

“Then the master told us about the different kinds of ships—those that sail on the sea, those that sail on the land, and those that sail through the air.”

“Are there ships that sail through the air?” Alice asked.

“Of course,” said the Gryphon. “They’re called ‘airships’.”

“Then we had a lesson on the different kinds of dances,” the Mock Turtle went on. “First, the Lobster Quadrille, then the Turtle’s Hornpipe, and lastly the Seaweed Waltz.”

“Would you like to dance the Lobster Quadrille?” asked the Gryphon.

“Yes, please!” said Alice eagerly.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

events.title: Arrival at the Trial and Initial Observations
detailed_summary: Alice enters the scene to find the King and Queen of Hearts presiding over a trial from their throne.
A diverse crowd of small animals, birds, and the entire deck of cards surrounds them.
The Knave of Hearts stands accused, bound in chains and guarded by soldiers.
The White Rabbit is present in the role of a court herald, equipped with a trumpet and a parchment scroll.
A table displaying a large dish of tarts captures Alice's attention, making her hungry and wish for the trial to conclude quickly so refreshments could be served.
Recognizing the improbability of immediate refreshments, Alice decides to observe the proceedings to occupy her time.
Although new to a real court of justice, Alice's reading allows her to identify various elements.
She correctly identifies the King as the judge, noting his large wig worn awkwardly beneath his crown.
Alice also identifies the jury-box and its twelve occupants, a mix of animals and birds, whom she proudly labels "jurors," reflecting on the advanced vocabulary for her age.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

events.text_segment:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—“I wish they’d get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!” But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. “That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “because of his great wig.”
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
“And that’s the jury-box,” thought Alice, “and those twelve creatures,” (she was obliged to say “creatures,” you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) “I suppose they are the jurors.” She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

**Simulated Output:**

The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.

Alice looked around in wonder at the curious assembly. The King wore a large, awkward wig beneath his crown, clearly acting as judge, while the Queen sat sternly beside him. Surrounding them was a motley crowd of animals and birds, mingled with the entire pack of cards, who formed the jury-box. Alice counted twelve occupants there, proudly thinking to herself that she knew the word "jurors" from her reading.

Her eyes then fell upon a table nearby, piled high with a large dish of tarts. The sight made her stomach rumble, and she wished the trial would hurry so that refreshments might be served. But knowing that such things rarely happened quickly in courts, she settled down to watch the proceedings with keen interest.

**Simulated Output:**

The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.

In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: this caught Alice’s eye, and made her quite hungry. She thought to herself how she wished the trial would be over, and the refreshments handed round.

But as it was clear that the trial would not end soon, Alice looked around to pass the time. She had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and was quite pleased to find that she could make out nearly everything.

She saw the King sitting on his throne as judge, with a large wig on his head, which looked very awkward beneath his crown (as shown in the frontispiece). Near him was the White Rabbit, holding a trumpet and a scroll.

Alice then noticed the jury-box, which was filled with twelve creatures—some animals and some birds. She repeated the word “jurors” two or three times to herself, feeling very proud to know it, and thought how few girls of her age would know the word. She reflected that “jury-men” would have been a simpler term, but since the jury was made up of different kinds of creatures, she was obliged to use the word “jurors.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The King laid his hand upon the scroll, and read out, 'The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, all on a summer day:'—
'Consider your verdict,' the King said to the jury.
'Not yet, not yet!' the Rabbit hastily interrupted; 'there's a great deal to come before that!'
'Call the first witness,' said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, 'First witness!'
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a saucer in the other, and the large hat-box still under his arm.
'Your name?' the King said.
'Why, I didn't think it mattered much,' said the Hatter.
'It must,' said the King.
'Well, then, I can't tell you my name, just at present,' the Hatter replied.
'You know that you are a juror?' said the King.
'I'll try to be,' the Hatter replied.
'What did you do with the tarts?' the Queen said to the Hatter.
'I couldn't have done it!' said the Hatter indignantly.
'Who did?' said the Queen.
'That's none of my business,' said the Hatter.
The King looked at the jury, who were all writing down on their slates, 'She can't have done it. She's innocent.'
The Queen said, 'Off with his head!'
'Hold your tongue!' said the King, 'order!'
The trial went on with many curious witnesses and strange evidence, until at last the King said, 'Call the next witness!'
And so the story continued, full of nonsense and whimsy, as only Wonderland could provide.

events.title: The Jury's Premature Actions
detailed_summary: Alice observes the twelve jurors busily writing on slates.
She curiously whispers to the Gryphon, asking what they could possibly be writing before the trial has even started.
The Gryphon explains in a whisper that the jurors are writing down their own names, fearing they might forget them before the trial concludes.
Alice begins to voice her indignation loudly, calling them "Stupid things!", but quickly falls silent as the White Rabbit demands order in the court.
Simultaneously, the King puts on his spectacles and scans the room, trying to identify the source of the interruption.
Alice can clearly see the jurors' slates, confirming they are indeed writing "stupid things!".
She notices one juror struggling to spell "stupid" and needing assistance from a neighbor.
Alice inwardly remarks on the chaotic state the jurors' notes will likely be in by the end of the trial.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

events.text_segment:
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”
“They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply, “for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”
“Stupid things!” Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, “Silence in the court!” and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down “stupid things!” on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell “stupid,” and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

events.title: Alice's Intervention and the Formal Accusation
detailed_summary: One juror possesses a pencil that emits a disruptive squeaking sound.
Finding the noise intolerable, Alice moves around the court until she is behind the juror.
She deftly seizes an opportunity to snatch the pencil away unnoticed.
The juror, identified as Bill the Lizard, is completely baffled by the pencil's sudden disappearance.
After a futile search, Bill resorts to writing with his finger for the remainder of the day, which proves ineffective as it leaves no marks on the slate.
The King then instructs the Herald (White Rabbit) to formally read the charges.
Following the King's command, the White Rabbit produces three blasts from his trumpet.
He then unrolls the parchment scroll and recites the accusation: a nursery rhyme detailing how the Knave of Hearts allegedly stole the Queen's tarts.
Immediately upon hearing the charges, the King instructs the jury to deliberate and reach their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

events.text_segment:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
“Herald, read the accusation!” said the King.
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
“The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
    All on a summer day:
The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
    And took them quite away!”
“Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, made a very irritating noise, and Alice could not help fancying that it must have a tendency to squeak in her ear all the time. She went round the court, and got behind him, and then she slipped the pencil out of his hand. The poor juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) looked at his hand, all round, to find out what had become of the pencil; but it was quite plain that he could not make it out. He began to write with his finger on the slate; but he could not make any mark with his finger, and he was fidgeting so much that he could not write at all. The King then said, "Hold your tongues!" and added, "I order and direct that the Herald shall read the accusation." On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—

"'The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
All on a summer day:
The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
And took them quite away!'

"Consider your verdict," the King said to the jury.

The Queen of Hearts, known for her quick temper, kept shouting, "Off with their heads!" at the slightest provocation. Alice, sitting quietly among the spectators, found the whole scene utterly bewildering. The evidence presented was nonsensical, and the rules of the court seemed to change with every moment. Despite the chaos, the trial continued, with the jury deliberating over the most absurd accusations. Alice couldn't help but wonder how such a trial could ever reach a fair conclusion in a land where logic was turned upside down.

events.title: The Hatter's Arrival and Confusing Testimony
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit quickly intervenes, telling the King it's too early for a verdict as much evidence is yet to be presented.
The King concedes and requests the first witness.
The White Rabbit blows his trumpet again and summons the "First witness!"
The Hatter enters, still holding his teacup and a piece of bread-and-butter.
He apologizes to the King for bringing his tea things, explaining he was summoned before finishing.
The King retorts that he should have finished and inquires when he started his tea.
The Hatter looks towards the March Hare, who has entered with the Dormouse, and guesses the date was March 14th.
The March Hare corrects him, stating it was the 15th; the Dormouse adds it was the 16th.
The King instructs the jury to write down all three dates, which they do eagerly, before attempting to convert the dates into monetary values.
The King then orders the Hatter to remove his hat.
The Hatter replies that the hat is not his.
The King immediately concludes the hat must be "Stolen!" and directs the jury to record this, which they do instantly.
The Hatter clarifies that he is a hatter by trade and keeps hats for sale, possessing none of his own.
At this point, the Queen puts on her spectacles and begins to stare intently at the Hatter, making him turn pale and fidget nervously.
The King demands the Hatter give his evidence, warning him not to be nervous under threat of immediate execution.
This threat fails to calm the Hatter; he shifts anxiously from foot to foot, glancing worriedly at the Queen, and in his disarray, bites a chunk out of his teacup instead of his bread-and-butter.
Simultaneously, Alice becomes aware of a peculiar physical sensation and realizes she has begun to grow taller again; considering leaving, she ultimately decides to stay as long as space permits.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

events.text_segment:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to come before that!”
“Call the first witness,” said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, “First witness!”
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I beg pardon, your Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.”
“You ought to have finished,” said the King. “When did you begin?”
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. “Fourteenth of March, I think it was,” he said.
“Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.
“Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.
“Write that down,” the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
“Take off your hat,” the King said to the Hatter.
“It isn’t mine,” said the Hatter.
“Stolen!” the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
“I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none of my own. I’m a hatter.”
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
“Give your evidence,” said the King; “and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.”
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Not yet, not yet!" the Rabbit hastily interrupted. "There’s a great deal to come before that!"

"Call the first witness," said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, "First witness!"

The Hatter came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other; he came in with a great hurry, and looked at the Queen, and said, "I beg pardon, your Majesty, for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for."

"You ought to have finished," said the King. "When did you begin?"

The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, and said, "Fourteenth of March, I think it was."

"Fifteenth," said the March Hare.

"Sixteenth," said the Dormouse.

"Write that down," the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.

"Take off your hat," the King said to the Hatter.

"I won’t," said the Hatter.

"Then you shall have no pudding," said the King.

"I don’t care for pudding," said the Hatter.

"Then you shall have no bread-and-butter," the King said.

"I don’t care for that either," said the Hatter.

"Then you shall be executed," said the King.

"That’s all one to me," said the Hatter.

"But I don’t want to go about mad," said Alice.

"Oh, you can’t help that," said the King: "we’re all mad here. I’m mad. You’re mad."

"How do you know I’m mad?" said Alice.

"You must be," said the King, "or you wouldn’t have come here."

The Hatter began to look rather uncomfortable, and the Queen put on her spectacles and began to look at him very hard.

"Give your evidence," said the King; "and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot."

This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, and looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.

Alice could hardly keep from laughing when she saw this; but on the other hand, she was rather uncomfortable, as it was all quite new to her, and she felt very large again.

She thought she would leave as soon as she had an opportunity, but she could not get out of the court, and she began to grow taller and taller, so that she was nearly as tall as the roof; and she thought at last she would get up and leave, but she could not find any way out.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to be done before the trial. We must have everything in order.” Alice looked around, bewildered by the sudden seriousness of the White Rabbit. The court was a curious place, filled with the most extraordinary creatures, all bustling about with a sense of urgency.

The King of Hearts was presiding over the trial, his face flushed with importance. The Queen sat beside him, her eyes flashing with impatience. The Knave of Hearts stood accused of stealing the tarts, and the courtroom was filled with witnesses and jurors, all eager to hear the evidence.

Alice found herself drawn into the proceedings, her curiosity piqued by the strange and nonsensical nature of the trial. The witnesses gave their testimonies in the most peculiar ways, some speaking in riddles, others in rhymes. The Mad Hatter and the March Hare were among the spectators, their faces twisted into expressions of amusement and confusion.

As the trial progressed, Alice began to see the absurdity of the situation. The rules of logic and reason seemed to have no place here. The Queen of Hearts shouted, “Off with his head!” at the slightest provocation, and the King tried to maintain order, though his efforts were often in vain.

Alice felt a growing sense of frustration. “This is the silliest trial I ever heard of!” she exclaimed. “Why, it’s all nonsense!”

Just then, the White Rabbit returned, holding a large book. “Order! Order!” he cried. “We must proceed with the evidence.”

The trial continued, with more strange testimonies and bewildering arguments. Alice listened carefully, determined to understand the truth behind the accusations. But as the chaos unfolded, she realized that in Wonderland, nothing was quite as it seemed, and the only way to make sense of it all was to embrace the madness.

events.title: Alice's Growth Spurt Causes Conflict
detailed_summary: The Dormouse, positioned next to the rapidly growing Alice, complains about being squeezed and unable to breathe properly.
Alice responds meekly, stating she cannot control her growth.
The Dormouse counters that she has no entitlement to grow specifically within the confines of the court.
Alice dismisses this argument more assertively, pointing out that the Dormouse is also subject to growth.
The Dormouse insists its own growth occurs at a 'reasonable pace,' unlike Alice's 'ridiculous fashion'.
Visibly annoyed, the Dormouse gets up and moves to the other side of the courtroom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.

events.text_segment:
“I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. “I can hardly breathe.”
“I can’t help it,” said Alice very meekly: “I’m growing.”
“You’ve no right to grow here,” said the Dormouse.
“Don’t talk nonsense,” said Alice more boldly: “you know you’re growing too.”
“Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,” said the Dormouse: “not in that ridiculous fashion.” And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.

events.title: Hatter's Testimony Continues Amidst Threats and Chaos
detailed_summary: Throughout Alice's growth incident, the Queen maintains her intense stare at the Hatter.
As the Dormouse relocates, the Queen instructs a court officer to fetch the list of singers from the last concert.
This request causes the Hatter extreme distress; he trembles so severely that both his shoes fall off.
The King angrily reiterates his demand for evidence, threatening execution again, irrespective of the Hatter's nervousness.
The Hatter begins a shaky, incoherent testimony, mentioning poverty, unfinished tea, thin bread-and-butter, and the 'twinkling' of the tea.
The King interrupts, questioning the concept of 'twinkling tea,' leading to a nonsensical debate about the letter 'T'.
The Hatter resumes, claiming 'most things twinkled' and attempting to attribute a statement to the March Hare.
The March Hare immediately denies it; the Hatter insists, but the King rules to disregard that part of the testimony.
The Hatter then tries to quote the Dormouse, looking around nervously, but the Dormouse offers no denial, being deeply asleep.
He mentions cutting more bread-and-butter.
A juror asks what the Dormouse said.
The Hatter admits he cannot recall.
The King declares the Hatter must remember or face execution.
Overwhelmed, the Hatter drops his teacup and bread-and-butter, falling to one knee and pleading poverty.
The King dismisses him as a 'very poor speaker.'
One of the guinea-pig observers cheers and is immediately 'suppressed' by court officers stuffing it into a canvas bag and sitting on it.
Alice mentally notes this clarifies the meaning of 'suppression' she'd read about.
The King tells the Hatter he may 'stand down,' assuming this concludes his testimony.
The Hatter, still kneeling, replies he cannot go any lower.
The King corrects himself, telling the Hatter he may 'sit down.'
The other guinea-pig cheers and is similarly suppressed.
Alice thinks the guinea-pig interruptions are over, hoping for progress.
The Hatter expresses a desire to finish his tea, looking anxiously at the Queen, who is preoccupied with the singers' list.
The King permits the Hatter to leave.
The Hatter departs hastily, forgetting his shoes.
The Queen issues an order to an officer to behead the Hatter outside, but the Hatter has already vanished from sight.

events.text_segment:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
“Give your evidence,” the King repeated angrily, “or I’ll have you executed, whether you’re nervous or not.”
“I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, “—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—”
“The twinkling of the what?” said the King.
“It began with the tea,” the Hatter replied.
“Of course twinkling begins with a T!” said the King sharply. “Do you take me for a dunce? Go on!”
“I’m a poor man,” the Hatter went on, “and most things twinkled after that—only the March Hare said—”
“I didn’t!” the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
“You did!” said the Hatter.
“I deny it!” said the March Hare.
“He denies it,” said the King: “leave out that part.”
“Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said—” the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
“After that,” continued the Hatter, “I cut some more bread-and-butter—”
“But what did the Dormouse say?” one of the jury asked.
“That I can’t remember,” said the Hatter.
“You must remember,” remarked the King, “or I’ll have you executed.”
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” he began.
“You’re a very poor speaker,” said the King.
Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
“I’m glad I’ve seen that done,” thought Alice. “I’ve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, “There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court,” and I never understood what it meant till now.”
“If that’s all you know about it, you may stand down,” continued the King.
“I can’t go no lower,” said the Hatter: “I’m on the floor, as it is.”
“Then you may sit down,” the King replied.
Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
“Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!” thought Alice. “Now we shall get on better.”
“I’d rather finish my tea,” said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
“You may go,” said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
“—and just take his head off outside,” the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.

The Hatter trembled so, that he dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee.

“I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” he began again.

“You’re a very poor speaker,” said the King.

At this moment one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court, who stuffed it into a canvas bag, and sat upon it.

Alice thought this was quite out of order, and she began to feel very uneasy.

“Suppressed!” she said to herself. “I’d like to know what that means.”

The King said to the Hatter, “You may stand down.”

“I can’t stand up,” said the Hatter; “I’m on the floor—”

“Then you may sit down,” the King corrected himself.

Another guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed in the same manner.

Alice thought the guinea-pigs were an excellent example of suppression, and she hoped they would not suppress her.

The Hatter said, “I wish to finish my tea.”

The Queen was looking at the list of singers, and did not hear.

The King said, “You may go.”

The Hatter hurriedly left the court, forgetting his shoes.

“Off with his head!” the Queen shouted to one of the officers, who was going to do it when the Hatter had disappeared.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.

“Why, I wouldn’t be so sure of that!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re singing about!”

The Queen turned sharply to Alice. “Off with her head!” she cried.

“No, no!” said the King, “be patient! Let’s hear what the song is first.”

The Hatter, still trembling, was handed the list. He read aloud, “Twinkle, twinkle, little bat! How I wonder what you’re at! Up above the world you fly, like a tea-tray in the sky.”

The Queen’s face softened a little. “That’s nonsense,” she said. “Off with his head!”

“Hold your tongue!” said the King, “and don’t be so quick to judge.”

Alice looked around at the crowd. The Knave of Hearts was standing before the throne, looking very uncomfortable. “What’s going to happen to him?” she whispered to the Gryphon.

“Why, he’s to be tried for stealing the tarts,” said the Gryphon.

“Stole the tarts!” exclaimed Alice. “I never heard of such a thing!”

“Hold your tongue!” said the Queen, turning to Alice. “You’re not on trial here.”

The trial began. The King of Hearts was the judge, the Queen was the jury, and the Hatter was the witness. The Mad Hatter was called to the stand.

“Where were you on the day of the tarts’ disappearance?” asked the King.

“I was at the tea party,” said the Hatter.

“Did you see the Knave of Hearts near the tarts?”

“No, Your Majesty.”

“Are you sure?”

“Quite sure.”

The Queen was getting impatient. “Off with his head!” she shouted.

“Sentence first—verdict afterwards,” said the King.

The White Rabbit came forward with a paper. “Here is the evidence,” he said, handing it to the King.

The King read aloud, “The tarts were stolen by the Knave of Hearts.”

“Silence!” cried the Queen. “Off with his head!”

Alice stood up. “You’re all mad!” she said. “I won’t stand for this nonsense.”

The Queen screamed, “Off with her head!”

But Alice was no longer afraid. She looked around and saw that the Queen and her court were nothing but a pack of cards. She laughed and laughed until she woke up in her own garden, the adventure over.

events.title: The Cook's Brief Appearance and the Dormouse's Ejection
detailed_summary: The King calls for the next witness.
The Duchess's cook enters, carrying her pepper-box.
Alice immediately recognizes her, partly because people near the entrance begin sneezing uncontrollably.
The King requests her evidence.
The cook bluntly refuses, stating, "Shan't."
The King looks uncertainly at the White Rabbit, who quietly advises that His Majesty must cross-examine this witness.
Resignedly, the King accepts, folds his arms, frowns deeply at the cook, and asks in a solemn voice what tarts are composed of.
The cook replies, "Pepper, mostly."
A sleepy voice from behind the cook (the Dormouse) contradicts, suggesting "Treacle."
The Queen erupts in fury, ordering the Dormouse to be captured, beheaded, thrown out of court, suppressed, pinched, and have its whiskers removed.
A chaotic period ensues as court officers attempt to carry out the Queen's contradictory orders regarding the Dormouse.
By the time the confusion subsides and the Dormouse has been ejected, the cook has discreetly disappeared.
The King expresses considerable relief at the cook's departure and promptly calls for the next witness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Call the next witness!” said the King.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.”

events.text_segment:
“Call the next witness!” said the King.
The next witness was the Duchess’s cook. She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
“Give your evidence,” said the King.
“Shan’t,” said the cook.
The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, “Your Majesty must cross-examine this witness.”
“Well, if I must, I must,” the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, “What are tarts made of?”
“Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.
“Treacle,” said a sleepy voice behind her.
“Collar that Dormouse,” the Queen shrieked out. “Behead that Dormouse! Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!”
For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
“Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.”

events.title: Alice Called as the Next Witness
detailed_summary: The King speaks quietly to the Queen, suggesting she should handle the cross-examination of the upcoming witness, complaining that the effort is giving him a headache.
Alice watches the White Rabbit consult his list, feeling curious about who the next witness might be.
She internally reflects on the lack of substantial evidence presented thus far in the trial.
To Alice's utter astonishment, the White Rabbit, in his high-pitched voice, reads out her own name: "Alice!"

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name “Alice!”

events.text_segment:
And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”
Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like, “—for they haven’t got much evidence yet,” she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name “Alice!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”

The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at the King for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with his head!”

“Hold your noise!” said the King, and the Queen was silent.

“—and now, Alice, my dear,” said the King, “tell us your evidence.”

“I’m afraid I can’t remember much yet,” Alice said very politely, “I’m afraid I can’t remember things as I used to do: and I don’t see the meaning of all this.”

“Explain all this!” said the Queen.

“Explain what?” said Alice.

“Why, the trial, of course.”

“Why, I didn’t know it was a trial,” said Alice.

“Come, that’s a good thing, at any rate,” said the King.

“Now, I give my evidence,” said Alice, “and I’ll tell you what I know.”

The White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then said, “Silence in the court!”

“Herald, read the accusation!”

The White Rabbit read out, in a shrill, squeaking voice, “The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, all on a summer day: The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts, and took them quite away!”

“Did you say ‘tarts’?” said Alice.

“I did,” said the White Rabbit.

“Why, they’re mine,” said Alice.

“Silence!” shouted the Queen.

“Order!” cried the King.

“Now, Alice,” said the King, “tell us what you know about the tarts.”

Alice looked at the jury, and then at the Queen, and then at the King, and then at the White Rabbit, and then at the Knave of Hearts, and then at the Queen again.

“I’m afraid I can’t tell you much,” she said at last. “I only know that the Knave of Hearts did not steal the tarts.”

“Who says he did?” said the Queen.

“Why, you did,” said Alice.

“Who are you?” said the Queen.

“Why, I’m Alice,” said Alice.

“Off with her head!” screamed the Queen.

“Hold your noise!” said the King, and the Queen was silent.

“Call the next witness!” said the King.

The White Rabbit consulted his list, and then said, in a high-pitched voice, “Alice!”

events.title: Alice Disrupts the Court and Upsets the Jury
detailed_summary: Forgetting her recent growth spurt in the heat of the moment, Alice jumps up and accidentally knocks over the jury box with her skirt.
The jurymen tumble out onto the crowd below, reminding Alice of goldfish she once spilled.
Feeling dismayed, Alice quickly starts picking up the jurymen, worried they might perish if not returned to the box immediately, like the goldfish.
The King solemnly declares the trial cannot continue until every juryman is back in their correct place, emphasizing the point while looking pointedly at Alice.
Alice notices she put the Lizard back upside down in her haste; it waves its tail helplessly.
She rights the Lizard, though she privately muses that its orientation likely makes no difference to its usefulness in the trial.
Once the jury recovers and gets their slates and pencils back, they diligently begin writing an account of the disruption.
The Lizard, however, seems too stunned to do anything but sit with its mouth open, staring at the ceiling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

events.text_segment:
“Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
“Oh, I beg your pardon!” she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
“The trial cannot proceed,” said the King in a very grave voice, “until all the jurymen are back in their proper places—all,” he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got it out again, and put it right; “not that it signifies much,” she said to herself; “I should think it would be quite as much use in the trial one way up as the other.”
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Here!" cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.

"Oh, I beg your pardon!" she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head. "You are all right, my dear?" she said, addressing them kindly, and looking down with one eye; but it was too much to hope that they could all answer her. "Not one of them seems to be hurt," she said, in a tone of great relief, and she tried to put them back into the jury-box, but it was quite out of her reach: she could see their little legs and arms waving about in all directions, and the poor little Lizard, who was upside down, was waving its tail helplessly in the air.

"Come, now!" said the King, "sit down, and don't keep the court waiting." Alice looked round, and saw that the jury were all getting up and scrambling back into the box, and the King added, "The trial cannot proceed till every juryman is back in his place."

Alice put the Lizard right side up, and it gave a little shake, and waved its tail again. "I don't think it matters much which way up you put him," she said to herself, "he's too much stunned to be of any use to the court."

The jurymen all got their slates and pencils, and began writing down the evidence, while the Lizard sat with its mouth open, staring at the ceiling.

events.title: Alice Testifies Ignorance Amidst Royal Confusion
detailed_summary: The King questions Alice about her knowledge of the matter at hand.
Alice replies that she knows nothing at all.
The King insists, asking if she knows absolutely nothing.
Alice confirms she knows nothing whatsoever.
The King declares her testimony "very important" and turns to the jury.
As the jury begins writing this down, the White Rabbit interjects respectfully, suggesting the King actually meant "unimportant", while subtly making critical faces at the King.
The King hastily agrees he meant "unimportant" and then mutters "important—unimportant" to himself, seemingly testing the words.
Alice observes that some jurors write "important" and others write "unimportant", but she thinks it makes no difference.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What do you know about this business?” the King said to Alice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; “but it doesn’t matter a bit,” she thought to herself.

events.text_segment:
“What do you know about this business?” the King said to Alice.
“Nothing,” said Alice.
“Nothing whatever?” persisted the King.
“Nothing whatever,” said Alice.
“That’s very important,” the King said, turning to the jury. They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted: “Unimportant, your Majesty means, of course,” he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
“Unimportant, of course, I meant,” the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone,
“important—unimportant—unimportant—important—” as if he were trying which word sounded best.
Some of the jury wrote it down “important,” and some “unimportant.” Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; “but it doesn’t matter a bit,” she thought to herself.

“Very important, your evidence is,” the King declared, turning to the jury. As they began to write, the White Rabbit stepped forward, bowing slightly. “If your Majesty would permit, I believe the word you meant was ‘unimportant’,” he said, casting a sly glance at the King.

The King blinked and nodded hastily. “Unimportant, of course—important—unimportant,” he muttered to himself, testing the words.

Alice noticed that some jurymen wrote down ‘important’ while others wrote ‘unimportant’, but she thought it made no difference either way.

events.title: Rule Forty-Two and Alice's Logical Defiance
detailed_summary: The King, after writing in his notebook, shouts for silence and reads "Rule Forty-two": anyone over a mile high must leave court.
All eyes turn to Alice.
Alice protests that she is not a mile high.
The King contradicts her, and the Queen adds that Alice is nearly two miles high.
Alice firmly states she won't leave, asserting the rule is irregular and just invented by the King.
The King claims it's the oldest rule in the book.
Alice retorts that, if true, it should logically be Rule Number One.
Visibly flustered, the King turns pale, snaps his notebook shut, and nervously tells the jury to consider their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

events.text_segment:
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.”
Everybody looked at Alice.
“I’m not a mile high,” said Alice.
“You are,” said the King.
“Nearly two miles high,” added the Queen.
“Well, I shan’t go, at any rate,” said Alice: “besides, that’s not a regular rule: you invented it just now.”
“It’s the oldest rule in the book,” said the King.
“Then it ought to be Number One,” said Alice.
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

events.title: Mysterious Unsigned Verses Presented as Evidence
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit hastily interrupts, announcing new evidence in the form of a recently found paper.
The Queen inquires about its contents.
The Rabbit explains it appears to be a letter from the prisoner to someone, but he hasn't opened it yet.
The King speculates it must be addressed to someone, unless, unusually, it was written to nobody.
A juryman asks who it is addressed to.
The Rabbit reveals it has no address and nothing written on the outside.
He unfolds the paper and clarifies it's not a letter but a set of verses.
Another juryman asks if the verses are in the prisoner's handwriting.
The Rabbit replies that they are not, which he finds very peculiar, baffling the jury.
The King suggests the prisoner must have imitated someone else's handwriting, which seems to satisfy the jury.
The Knave speaks up, denying he wrote it and stating they cannot prove he did, as there is no signature.
The King illogically argues that not signing makes matters worse, implying mischievous intent, a statement met with applause as his first clever remark.
The Queen declares the Knave's guilt proven by this.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.

events.text_segment:
“There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
“What’s in it?” said the Queen.
“I haven’t opened it yet,” said the White Rabbit, “but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.”
“It must have been that,” said the King, “unless it was written to nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.”
“Who is it directed to?” said one of the jurymen.
“It isn’t directed at all,” said the White Rabbit; “in fact, there’s nothing written on the outside.” He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added “It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.”
“Are they in the prisoner’s handwriting?” asked another of the jurymen.
“No, they’re not,” said the White Rabbit, “and that’s the queerest thing about it.” (The jury all looked puzzled.)
“He must have imitated somebody else’s hand,” said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)
“Please your Majesty,” said the Knave, “I didn’t write it, and they can’t prove I did: there’s no name signed at the end.”
“If you didn’t sign it,” said the King, “that only makes the matter worse. You must have meant some mischief, or else you’d have signed your name like an honest man.”
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
“That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.

“What’s in it?” said the King, looking over the paper, but very quickly, before the White Rabbit could read it out.

“It’s a letter, written by the prisoner to— to somebody,” the Rabbit said in a hurried tone; “I can’t make out who it’s to.”

“Read it,” said the King.

The Rabbit read the letter aloud:

‘“Dear Sir, I wish you would have the kindness to take care of my poor little Alice. She is very fond of you, and I am sure you will be very kind to her.”’

“Who is it from?” asked the King.

“That’s just what I want to find out,” said the Rabbit. “It’s signed with a name I don’t know.”

“Let me see it,” said the King, taking the paper. “It’s signed ‘The Queen of Hearts.’”

“Then it’s all right,” said the King, looking pleased. “The Queen of Hearts is always very kind to Alice.”

“Now, then,” said the King, “we must hear the evidence. Call the first witness.”

The White Rabbit hurried away, and soon returned with a Mouse, who looked very nervous and uncomfortable.

“Are you ready to give your evidence?” asked the King.

“I—I hardly know what to say,” stammered the Mouse.

“Tell us everything you know,” said the King.

“Well,” said the Mouse, “I was in the garden when I saw the prisoner take the tarts.”

“Did you see the prisoner take the tarts?” asked the King.

“Yes,” said the Mouse.

“Then that is enough,” said the King. “Call the next witness.”

events.title: Nonsensical Poem Reading and Absurd Interpretation
detailed_summary: Alice interjects, stating the verses prove nothing as their meaning is unknown.
The King instructs the White Rabbit to read the verses.
The Rabbit puts on spectacles and asks where to start.
The King gravely tells him to begin at the beginning, continue to the end, and then stop.
The White Rabbit reads a nonsensical poem involving pronouns, swimming ability, gifts, and secrets.
The King declares the poem the most important evidence yet and prepares to instruct the jury.
Alice, now larger and bolder, interrupts, offering money to anyone who can explain the poem, stating her belief that it lacks any meaning.
The jury members write down Alice's disbelief but don't try to interpret the verses.
The King initially suggests that meaninglessness simplifies things, but then reconsiders, attempting to decipher the poem.
He connects a line about not swimming to the Knave, who confirms his inability to swim.
He links lines about giving items to the tarts, declaring the connection obvious when Alice points out a line about items being returned.
He tries to link a line about a 'fit' to the Queen, who reacts furiously, denies having fits, and throws an inkstand at the Lizard.
The Lizard begins writing with the spilled ink.
The King concludes the words about fits don't suit the Queen, makes a pun on 'fit', and is offended by the silence before everyone laughs.
He repeats his instruction for the jury to consider their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

events.text_segment:
“It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
“Read them,” said the King.
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. “Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?” he asked.
“Begin at the beginning,” the King said gravely, “and go on till you come to the end: then stop.”
These were the verses the White Rabbit read:—
“They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.

He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?

I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.

If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.

My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.

Don’t let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.”
“That’s the most important piece of evidence we’ve heard yet,” said the King, rubbing his hands; “so now let the jury—”
“If any one of them can explain it,” said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn’t a bit afraid of interrupting him,) “I’ll give him sixpence. I don’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it.”
The jury all wrote down on their slates, “She doesn’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it,” but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
“If there’s no meaning in it,” said the King, “that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn’t try to find any. And yet I don’t know,” he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; “I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. “—said I could not swim—” you can’t swim, can you?” he added, turning to the Knave.
The Knave shook his head sadly. “Do I look like it?” he said. (Which he certainly did not, being made entirely of cardboard.)
“All right, so far,” said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: “‘We know it to be true—’ that’s the jury, of course—‘I gave her one, they gave him two—’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—”
“But, it goes on ‘they all returned from him to you,’” said Alice.
“Why, there they are!” said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table. “Nothing can be clearer than that. Then again—‘before she had this fit—’ you never had fits, my dear, I think?” he said to the Queen.
“Never!” said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
“Then the words don’t fit you,” said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.
“It’s a pun!” the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed, “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented dialogue and characters (such as the Mouse and Duck) that do not appear in this scene, replacing the actual participants and their interactions.
- The actual poem read by the White Rabbit is almost entirely omitted and replaced with unrelated, repetitive, and invented lines, as well as a long, nonsensical repetition of a single phrase.
- The completion fails to include the subsequent courtroom discussion, reactions, and analysis of the poem by the King, Alice, and other characters, which are essential to the structure of the original passage.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The specific content and structure of the poem read aloud are missing; the completion does not attempt to reproduce the verses or their sequence.
- The reactions of the King, Alice, the jury, and the Queen to the poem, including their dialogue and actions, are absent.
- The sequence of events following the reading of the poem, such as the King's interpretation, Alice's challenge, the jury's response, and the Queen's outburst, are not present.
- The conclusion of the scene, including the King's pun and the instruction to the jury, is missing.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion attributes lines and actions to the wrong characters (e.g., the Mouse and Duck instead of the White Rabbit, King, and Alice).
- The sequence of events is disrupted by the introduction of unrelated dialogue and invented actions, leading to a loss of narrative coherence.
- The invented poem and the excessive repetition of a single phrase do not reflect the structure, tone, or content of the original passage.
- The completion omits the courtroom setting and the logical progression of the trial scene, resulting in a significant deviation from the original context.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”

“Of course I do,” said the Mock Turtle angrily. “You’re enough to try the patience of an oyster!”

“I’m sorry,” said Alice, “I didn’t mean to offend you. But I don’t understand why you’re so upset.”

“Why, if you don’t know what they’re about, how can you say they prove nothing?” retorted the Mock Turtle.

Alice thought for a moment. “Well, I suppose I should listen more carefully,” she said.

“Exactly!” said the Gryphon. “You see, the moral of the story is that sometimes things aren’t as they seem, and you have to look beneath the surface.”

Alice nodded slowly. “I think I understand now. It’s like when I first came to Wonderland and everything was so strange and confusing.”

“Precisely,” said the Mock Turtle. “And that’s why it’s important to keep an open mind.”

Alice smiled. “Thank you for explaining it to me.”

“Anytime,” said the Gryphon. “Now, would you like to hear another story?”

“Yes, please!” said Alice eagerly.

And so the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon began to tell Alice more tales, each more curious and wonderful than the last, filling her mind with the magic and mystery of Wonderland.

events.title: Sentence Before Verdict and Alice's Final Rebellion
detailed_summary: The Queen interrupts the King's call for a verdict, demanding the sentence be given first.
Alice loudly protests this idea as illogical nonsense.
The Queen, turning purple with anger, orders Alice to be silent.
Alice defiantly refuses.
The Queen shrieks for Alice's execution.
Nobody in the court makes a move to carry out the order.
Alice, having reached her full height, dismisses the Queen and the entire court.
She declares that she doesn't care about them because they are nothing more than a pack of cards.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”

events.text_segment:
“No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”
“Stuff and nonsense!” said Alice loudly. “The idea of having the sentence first!”
“Hold your tongue!” said the Queen, turning purple.
“I won’t!” said Alice.
“Off with her head!” the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody moved.
“Who cares for you?” said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"No, no!" said the Queen. "Sentence first—verdict afterwards."

"Stuff and nonsense!" said Alice loudly.

The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed "Off with her head!"

"Who cares for you?" said Alice (she had grown to her full size by this time). "You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

At this the whole pack rose up into the air and came flying down upon her; she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.

events.title: The Sister Reflects and Begins Her Own Dream
characters: (in dream/memory: Alice, White Rabbit, Mouse, March Hare, Hatter, Dormouse, Queen, Duchess, Pig-baby, Gryphon, Lizard, Guinea-pigs, Mock Turtle)
detailed_summary: After Alice leaves, her sister remains seated just as she was.
She leans her head on her hand, watches the setting sun, and contemplates Alice's amazing adventures.
Gradually, the sister begins to enter a dream-like state herself.
She first dreams of Alice as a little girl, picturing her clasped hands and eager eyes, hearing her voice and seeing her characteristic head toss.
As she seems to listen, the real environment around her transforms, becoming populated by the strange figures from Alice's dream.
She senses the White Rabbit rushing through the grass, hears the Mouse splashing in the pool, the clatter of the Mad Tea Party, and the Queen's shrill orders for executions.
She recalls the pig-baby sneezing, crashing plates, the Gryphon's shriek, the Lizard's pencil squeaking, the suppressed guinea pigs, and the Mock Turtle's distant sobbing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool—she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution—once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it—once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.

events.text_segment:
But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers—she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that would always get into her eyes—and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister’s dream.
The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool—she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution—once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it—once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.

The Gryphon was shrieking, the Lizard was scribbling, the guinea-pigs were suppressed, and the Mock Turtle was sobbing in the distance.

And all the while, the sister sat still, watching the sun set, and dreaming of Alice's adventures in Wonderland.
